09/28/15 12:20 PM EDT
A conservative watchdog group has asked the Office of Congressional Ethics to investigate whether North Carolina GOP Rep. Mark Meadows improperly paid an employee severance.
The Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust wrote OCE a letter last week asking the panel to “immediately investigate and take appropriate action” into Meadows’ alleged breach of House Ethics Rules for paying his chief of staff after he no longer worked for the lawmaker.
Story Continued Below
“It appears Representative Meadows permitted a former employee to remain on payroll and violated the House Code of Official Conduct,” the group wrote.
FACT Executive Director Matthew Whitaker, a former U.S. attorney in Iowa, said that "one of the rock hard rules in all of the government, and certainly in Congress, is you can't pay someone who is not working."
Whitaker said the group is nonpartisan and is "equal opportunity" accountability group.
When asked about FACT's calls for an investigation, Meadows' spokeswoman Alyssa Farrah said “we are not aware of any rules barring severance."
She added: "Mr. Meadows’ commitment to being a good steward of taxpayer dollars is well-documented. At the end of both 2013 and 2014 Congressman Meadows returned over $100,000 remaining from his office budget to the American taxpayer."
POLITICO reported earlier this month that Meadows’ chief of staff Kenneth West stopped working for the North Carolina Republican on May 21, yet continued to be paid through Aug. 15. A Meadow’s spokeswoman at the time said West was paid for “vacation and severance.”
But severance pay appears to be against House rules. The House Ethics Manual says, “compensation may be received only for duties performed within the preceding month.” Additionally, the Members’ Congressional Handbook says an employee must “perform official duties commensurate with the compensation received.”
Additionally, if a congressional aide is given a lump-sum payment, it must be disclosed separately. In House disbursement records, Meadows reported West's pay from May through August as regular compensation, though he changed West's position to "senior advisor."
